bio:treatment.description: Branches articulated, often swollen at nodes, usually differentiated into long and short shoots, hairs simple. Leaves petiolate or sessile, salt crystals usually present on leaf surfaces, sometimes forming solid crust, short-shoot leaves in axillary fascicles; petiole sometimes inconspicuous,
United States, Mexico, South America, Eurasia, Africa, Atlantic Islands, Australia; introduced in West Indies.
bio:treatment.discussion: Species ca. 70 (5 in the flora): United States, Mexico, South America, Eurasia, Africa, Atlantic Islands, Australia; introduced in West Indies.

Frankenia species vary in the degree of revoluteness of the leaf margins. This is most easily determined on fresh or softened material; loosely revolute margins will often tend to become somewhat more revolute on drying but can still be distinguished from tightly revolute margins that are not readily unrolled.

references.reference: Whalen, M. A. 1987. Systematics of Frankenia (Frankeniaceae) in North and South America. Syst. Bot. Monogr. 17: 1–93.
